citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two dogs were in need of veterinary care that had not been provided veterinary care at the time of inspection. The first
dog was an approximately 3 year old female poodle (microchip #900217000187655) that had wounds covering its body.
In addition, the dog was limping on its left rear leg. The licensee stated the dog was in a dog fight two days ago.
Another dog, an approximately 7 year old female poodle (microchip #900111881600916), had an open wound on its
abdomen. I originally observed the dog sitting in the corner with a black substance on the upper part of its left rear leg.
Upon closer observation, I observed an open wound on its abdomen and a reddish/pinkish liquid oozing/dripping off of the
dog. In addition, the dog appeared to have a very difficult time moving around and appeared to be either extremely
uncomfortable or in pain. The dog seemed to be lethargic.
Not providing adequate veterinary care doesn't ensure the well being of either dog. Both dogs appear to be uncomfortable
and in pain. Untreated open wounds can become infected and cause further problems.
The licensee must have both dogs examined by the attending veterinarian so that an accurate diagnosis can be made,
and an appropriate treatment plan can be developed and followed. The licensee must ensure that all animals receive
adequate veterinary care at all times by providing the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat
diseases and injuries.
Correct by 7/22/25.
Note: The licensee contacted the attending veterinarian during inspection and the attending veterinarian will be coming
out to examine both dogs today.

At the time of inspection there was no written exercise plan available for review despite dogs over 12 weeks of age being
present at the facility. Exercise for dogs is critical for healthy development and psychological well-being. The licensee
must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In addition, the
plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must include written standard procedures to be followed in
providing the opportunity for exercise. Correct starting on 8/22/25.

During the inspection, I observed a Golden Retreiver trying to stick its head under the fence to lick up the water that
pooled up under the watering nipple in the enclosure adjacent to it's enclosure. I asked the licensee to test the watering
nipple and no water was coming out when she pushed down on it. She provided the three dogs in that enclosure with a
bowl of water and I observed them to be drinking out of that bowl non-stop for approximately 30-45 seconds.
Dogs that don't have access to water can result in the dog becoming sick and potentially lead to death. It is important for
all dogs to have continuous access to potable water to maintain good health and hydration. Correct by making sure all
watering nipples are in working order and/or providing all dogs continuous access to potable water. Correct starting on
7/22/25.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two dogs were in need of veterinary care that had not been provided veterinary care at the time of inspection. The first 
dog was an approximately 3 year old female poodle (microchip #900217000187655) that had wounds covering its body. 
In addition, the dog was limping on its left rear leg. The licensee stated the dog was in a dog fight two days ago. 
 
Another dog, an approximately 7 year old female poodle (microchip #900111881600916), had an open wound on its 
abdomen. I originally observed the dog sitting in the corner with a black substance on the upper part of its left rear leg. 
Upon closer observation, I observed an open wound on its abdomen and a reddish/pinkish liquid oozing/dripping off of the 
dog. In addition, the dog appeared to have a very difficult time moving around and appeared to be either extremely 
uncomfortable or in pain. The dog seemed to be lethargic. 
 
Not providing adequate veterinary care doesn't ensure the well being of either dog. Both dogs appear to be uncomfortable 
and in pain. Untreated open wounds can become infected and cause further problems. 
 
The licensee must have both dogs examined by the attending veterinarian so that an accurate diagnosis can be made, 
and an appropriate treatment plan can be developed and followed. The licensee must ensure that all animals receive 
adequate veterinary care at all times by providing the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat 
diseases and injuries. 
 
Correct by 7/22/25. 
 
Note: The licensee contacted the attending veterinarian during inspection and the attending veterinarian will be coming 
out to examine both dogs today. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
At the time of inspection there was no written exercise plan available for review despite dogs over 12 weeks of age being 
present at the facility. Exercise for dogs is critical for healthy development and psychological well-being. The licensee 
must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In addition, the

plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must include written standard procedures to be followed in 
providing the opportunity for exercise. Correct starting on 8/22/25. 
3.10(a)  Direct
   
Watering 
During the inspection, I observed a Golden Retreiver trying to stick its head under the fence to lick up the water that 
pooled up under the watering nipple in the enclosure adjacent to it's enclosure. I asked the licensee to test the watering 
nipple and no water was coming out when she pushed down on it. She provided the three dogs in that enclosure with a 
bowl of water and I observed them to be drinking out of that bowl non-stop for approximately 30-45 seconds. 
 
Dogs that don't have access to water can result in the dog becoming sick and potentially lead to death. It is important for 
all dogs to have continuous access to potable water to maintain good health and hydration. Correct by making sure all 
watering nipples are in working order and/or providing all dogs continuous access to potable water. Correct starting on 
7/22/25. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report. 
 
 n
